description:
Neogale vison, commonly known as the American mink, is a semiaquatic mammal species belonging to the family Mustelidae. It is native to North America, ranging from Alaska and Canada to the southeastern United States.

The American mink is a small, slender, and agile predator with a streamlined body and short legs. Its fur is dense and velvety, typically dark brown or black in color, with a distinctive white patch on the chin and throat. The species is well-adapted to its aquatic lifestyle, with webbed feet and a tail that acts as a rudder, allowing it to swim efficiently in water.

Neogale vison is a carnivorous species, primarily feeding on small mammals, birds, fish, amphibians, and crustaceans. It is a skilled hunter, using its sharp teeth and claws to capture and consume its prey. The American mink is known for its territorial behavior and solitary nature, with adults typically living and hunting alone.

This species plays an important role in the ecosystem, acting as a top predator and helping to regulate the populations of its prey. Neogale vison is also valued for its high-quality fur, which has led to its commercial farming and trapping, although conservation efforts have been implemented in some regions to protect its populations.
